conclusion: Liquid will flow out from A, B, C, and D and needs to be predicted whether it flows into container E or F after passing through baffles.
Liquid starts flowing from points A, B, C, and D at the top, each stream having a different color: A (blue), B (light blue), C (yellow), and D (orange).
The liquids encounter several angled and horizontal baffles that guide and redirect their flow, including red and purple baffles and black and orange horizontal baffles at the bottom.
Stream A (blue) initially flows straight down, hits the red baffle, is redirected to the left, and continues flowing to the left, eventually reaching container E.
Stream B (light blue) initially flows straight down, hits the red baffle, is redirected to the right, and continues flowing to the right, eventually reaching container F.
Stream C (yellow) initially flows straight down, hits the purple baffle, is redirected to the right, and continues flowing to the right, eventually reaching container F.
Stream D (orange) initially flows straight down, hits the purple baffle, is redirected to the right, and continues flowing to the right, eventually reaching container F.
Container E receives only the blue liquid from stream A, while container F receives the light blue, yellow, and orange liquids from streams B, C, and D.
Based on the flow paths and interactions with the baffles, the liquid from A will flow into container E, while the liquids from B, C, and D will flow into container F.
